name: Propylamin trimethylaminum
Relationship: CHENOPODIUM VULARIA. The plant has an odor of decaying fish and contains a large amount of Propylamin. Weakness in lumbar and lower dorsal region.

Extremities: PAIN IN WRISTS AND ANKLES; worse, slightest motion
Rheumatism, needle held in fingers gets too heavy
Pain in wrist and ankle, unable to stand

details: In acute rheumatism, dissipates fever and pain in a day or two. Rheumatic prosopalgia, and rheumatic metastases, especially heart lesions.
dosage: Ten to fifteen drops, in about six ounces of water; teaspoonful doses every two hours.
